metadata.case_name: Messrs. Durga Dutt Chandi Prasad v. State of Bihar

facts.text: The firm of Messrs. Durga Dutt Chandi Prasad carried on business dealing in goods mostly raw jute at Sahebganj in Bihar.
Firm registered as a dealer under s. 4 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944, with effect from July 1, 1946.
Assessed to sales tax for periods: October 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948; April 1, 1948 to March 31, 1949; April 1, 1949 to March 31, 1950.

For first period (Oct 1947-Mar 1948), claimed deduction of Rs. 6,58,880-5-9 for purchases on behalf of Raigarh Jute Mills and Bengal Jute Mills outside Bihar, and Rs. 1,62,662-13-3 for despatches of jute to own firm in Calcutta.
Similar claims for second period (Apr 1948-Mar 1949) on same grounds.
For third period (Apr 1949-Mar 1950), similar claims plus deduction for sale of mustard seed worth Rs. 1,00,513-11-9 to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj.
Appellant claimed these were not sales within meaning of Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947.
Sales Tax Officer disallowed claims on June 7, 1951 for first two periods, and April 17, 1953 for third.
Appeals dismissed by Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Bihar.
Revisions under s.24 dismissed by Board of Revenue: August 20, 1953 and September 3, 1953 for first two periods; August 30, 1954 for third.
Board refused to state case to High Court under s.25(1), holding no questions of law arose; findings of fact conclusive.
High Court dismissed applications to direct Board to state case for first two periods: November 17, 1954.
For third period, High Court directed Board to state case on mustard seed deduction question.
High Court answered mustard seed question against appellant on January 21, 1957: no deduction as certificate lacked mention for manufacture.

Special leave granted by Supreme Court on December 23, 1955 from Board orders dated August 20/September 3, 1953 (first two periods) and August 30, 1954 (third period). No leave sought/granted from High Court orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to be heard on merits in the appeals when special leave was granted only from orders of Board of Revenue, bypassing High Court orders that have become final.
Whether despatch of jute outside Bihar was a sale within the meaning of the Act.
Whether purchases made on behalf of two mills outside Bihar were liable to tax.
Whether petitioner entitled to deduction for sale of mustard seed to Messrs. Panna Lal Binjraj under Schedule to Bihar Finance Act No.11 of 1949 read with Bihar Sales Tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Purchases on behalf of jute mills outside Bihar and despatches to own firm in Calcutta not sales under Act.
Leave granted under Art.136, so preliminary objection to hearing on merits should not be entertained.
Entitled to hearing on merits from Board orders despite High Court refusals.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: Appellant cannot bypass High Court orders that became final; no special circumstances for Art.136 exercise.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 136 Constitution; practice of Supreme Court

court_reasoning.text: Art.136 power discretionary, to be exercised sparingly in exceptional cases where substantial injustice done.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No exceptional circumstances; appellant seeks to ignore final High Court orders.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Bihar Sales Tax Act: facts final by authorities, law by High Court under s.25; cannot bypass High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Would lead to conflict of decisions.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Dhakeswari: no violation of natural justice here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Previous cases allowing bypass had special circumstances absent here.

court_reasoning.text: Practice of Court: will not entertain appeals from tribunal bypassing final High Court decisions under reference provisions.

holdings.text: Special leave not properly granted; improper exercise of discretion to hear merits by bypassing final High Court orders.

precedents_cited.relevance: Art.136 to be exercised sparingly in exceptional cases showing substantial injustice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.136 exercised due to violation of natural justice; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baldota Brothers v. Libra Mining Works
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can reconsider propriety of leave at hearing stage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Moti Ram v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Special leave in circumstance of property attachment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jogta Coal Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Decision on own facts re depreciation; not settling practice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Omar Salay Mohammed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Dhakeswari where findings based on suspicions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Special leave condoning delay beyond control.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Govindarajulu Mudaliar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot question tribunal after adverse final High Court order on reference application.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Chimmonlall Rameshwarlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismiss appeals without merits to avoid bypassing final High Court judgment on s.66(2).

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging, rate, assessment, appeal/revision/review, reference to High Court on questions of law.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Finance Act No.11 of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Deduction for sales to registered dealer for manufacture.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave to appeal from any court or tribunal; discretionary and sparingly exercised.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed without going into merits as special leave improperly granted; appellant cannot bypass final High Court orders by appealing directly from Board of Revenue orders under Art.136.

key_quotes.text: the wide discretionary power with which this Court is invested under it is to be exercised sparingly and in exceptional cases only
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits on Art.136 from Pritam Singh.

key_quotes.text: What the appellant is seeking to do now is to by-pass the High Court by ignoring its orders. This the appellant cannot be allowed to do.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We cannot by-pass the normal procedure which is to be adopted for this purpose and achieve the result indirectly in the manner suggested by the appellants.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Chimmonlall; against bypassing High Court.

key_quotes.text: special leave was not properly given in these cases and we would accordingly dismiss the appeals with costs, without going into merits.
key_quotes.speaker: court
